Issues.Title: Ivy : "Error in Node does not exist [...]"
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package When enabling Ivy and adding a dependency (in this cas, @angular/flex-layout) ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When adding a package to the application, and building the said app, an error such as ```bash Error in Node does not exist [path] ``` The problem have been reported several times and isn't resolved. It seems to come from NGCC and happens when a dependency of the added package isn't present in the app. In this case, it is due to @angular/cdk. Running ```bash npx ivy-ngcc -l debug ``` Seems to list the missing packages. Once the dependencies are added, everything works correctly. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ```bash ng new myApp npm i @angular/flex-layout # edit the app module to add the dependency ng build ``` ## üåç Your Environment Everything at the latest version (including node & npm) **Angular Version:**
**Anything else relevant?** I don't mind having to install the dependencies myslef, but at least th error should be clearer than that.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Ivy : "Error in Node does not exist [...]"" (#34858)

Issues.Title: Workspace Config Confusion
Issues.Body:
I am reading the documentation here: https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config

And I am not sure in what context you use 'inject' here:

The bundle is injected by default, but you can set inject to false to exclude the bundle from injection. For example, the following object values create and name a bundle that contains styles and scripts, and excludes it from injection:

"styles": [
  { "input": "src/external-module/styles.scss", "inject": false, "bundleName": "external-module" }
]

The bundle is injected by default? What bundle do you refer to and what do you mean by injected? Injected into what?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Workspace Config Confusion" (#34857)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support emitting a reference to interface declarations
Issues.Body:
In #34021 the ngtsc compiler gained the ability to emit type parameter
constraints, which would generate imports for any type reference that
is used within the constraint. However, the `AbsoluteModuleStrategy`
reference emitter strategy did not consider interface declarations as a
valid declaration it can generate an import for, throwing an error
instead.

This commit fixes the issue by including interface declarations in the
logic that determines whether something is a declaration.

Fixes #34837
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): support emitting a reference to interface declarations" (#34849)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): don't detect changes on detached child embedded views
Issues.Body:
Fixes Ivy detecting changes inside child embedded views, even though they're detached.

Note that there's one subtlety here: I made the changes inside `refreshDynamicEmbeddedViews` rather than `refreshView`, because we support detecting changes on a detached view (evidenced by a couple of unit tests), but only if it's triggered directly from the view's `ChangeDetectorRef`, however we shouldn't be detecting changes in the detached child view when something happens in the parent.

Fixes #34816.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): don't detect changes on detached child embedded views" (#34846)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure that `LOCALE_ID` is set after app initializers
Issues.Body:
Before ivy it was possible to configure a mutable service value
in an application initializer (by providing an `APP_INITIALIZER`)
that could be read in the provider of `LOCALE_ID`. This is a common
scenario if you wanted to load the locale id asynchronously from
an HTTP request for instance.

When using the ivy, the runtime needs to be told what the current
locale is, which is done by calling the `setLocaleId()` function with
the value injected by the `LOCALE_ID` token. Previously this was
being done before the application initializers were run, which meant
that the `LOCALE_ID` provider was being executed before the
app initializers had a chance to get a new value for it.

Now this initalization of the locale for the ivy runtime is done after the
application initializers have been run.

Closes #34701
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): ensure that `LOCALE_ID` is set after app initializers" (#34830)

Issues.Title: ci(docs-infra): do not output build progress for e2e tests on CI
Issues.Body:
When running the e2e tests on CI, it is desirable that the build progress is not logged, because that clutters the logs and makes it difficult to get to the useful info in case of failures.

The previous config to achieve that doesn't work any more.

This commit update the `ci` configuration for e2e tests to suppress build progress logging.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci(docs-infra): do not output build progress for e2e tests on CI" (#34840)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support @SkipSelf while injecting Injectors

Yes, worked in non-ivy.

Issues.Title: Usage of async before-each is wrong or at not described sufficiently
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description On the Testing Guide, in section 'Component Test Basics/Component DOM testing/CLI generated tests' there is an example that shows an initial spec file for the banner-external component. This test contains two before-each() declarations, one of them being async. However, there is nothing inside that is being awaited, thus it is very confusing why the async version of before-each() is used or needed. The describing text doesn't mention anything either. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/guide/testing ### Reproduction Steps** https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/guide/testing.md https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/examples/testing/src/app/banner/banner-external.component.spec.ts ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Actual: beforeEach(async(() => { TestBed.configureTestingModule({ declarations: [ BannerComponent ] }) .compileComponents(); })); beforeEach(() => { fixture = TestBed.createComponent(BannerComponent); component = fixture.componentInstance; fixture.detectChanges(); }); Expected: beforeEach(() => { TestBed.configureTestingModule({ declarations: [ BannerComponent ] }) .compileComponents(); fixture = TestBed.createComponent(BannerComponent); component = fixture.componentInstance; fixture.detectChanges(); }); ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment ### Browser info ### Anything else relevant?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Usage of async before-each is wrong or at not described sufficiently" (#34833)

Issues.Title: Ivy: "token must be defined" error when using components from an external module
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Ivy ### Is this a regression? It works with Ivy disabled but breaks with Ivy enabled. I'd consider this a regression but I do not know if it has worked in a previous version of Ivy. ### Description At runtime I get the error `token must be defined` and the browser stops at a breakpoint within the Angular code: ```js function throwError(msg) { // tslint:disable-next-line debugger; // Left intentionally for better debugger experience. throw new Error(`ASSERTION ERROR: ${msg}`); } ``` The immediate cause of the problem seems to be this code which is inside the precompiled ivy code: ```js SitesRowsLayoutComponent.…µfac = function SitesRowsLayoutComponent_Factory(t) { return new (t || SitesRowsLayoutComponent)(…µngcc0.…µ…µdirectiveInject(undefined)); }; ``` I think that `undefined` passed into `…µ…µdirectiveInject` is incorrect. The constructor of `SitesRowsLayoutComponent` is: ```typescript import { WCH_TOKEN_LOGGER_SERVICE } from '@acoustic-content-sdk/ng-api'; constructor( @Optional() @Inject(WCH_TOKEN_LOGGER_SERVICE) aLogSvc: LoggerService ) { ``` The `@acoustic-content-sdk/ng-api` is an npm module (https://www.npmjs.com/package/@acoustic-content-sdk/ng-api) generated using `ng-packagr`. The issue only occurs if `SitesRowsLayoutComponent` is in its own npm module (so that module gets precompiled by the ivy compiler) it does not occur if the component is declared in the application itself. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.9
Node: 10.17.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.0.0-rc.9
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: Regression problem in tsconfig.json outDir that cause VSCode showing errors in all import form libs poited with paths under /dist/...
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.3.23 ### Description The root tsconfig.json used in the new v9.0.0-rc* template point `"outDir": "./dist"` That caused annoying problem in VSCode when you rebuild libs referred by `"paths"` all the code `imports {...} from lib` is marked as Errors by TS because they are build under `/dist/...` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Run those commands: ``` npx @angular/cli@next new --createApplication=false my-workspace cd my-workspace npm run ng -- generate library my-lib npm run ng -- generate application my-app ``` The above commands are needed to setup the workspace for the repro with an application and a library pointed in the tsconfig.json ```"paths": { "my-lib": ["dist/my-lib"] }``` then add this line to app.module.ts to use the library inside the application: ``` // app.module.ts import { MyLibModule } from 'my-lib'; ``` and then run the compilation of the my-lib project in watch mode: ``` npm run ng -- build project=my-lib --watch ``` You will see in VSCode that all imports pointing to the my-lib will be signal as TS Errors 2307 ## üî• Exception or Error 

Can't find module 'my-lib' ts(2307)
## üåç Your Environment

Node: 12.14.1
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: ERROR in No NgModule metadata found for 'AppModule'

# üêû Bug report ### Command - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? It started happening in the same version without any version upgrade of any sort. ## Description There are 2 parts of the BUG. 1 during *serve* and 1 during *build* creation. ### Description During Serve If I need to tell this clearly, it can only be said that this bug occurred while doing development, And no changes to AppModule was made during that time. You hit npm start and you get the following error: *ERROR in No NgModule metadata found for 'AppModule'.* You save any file again and it will start compiling again and compile successfully. ### Description during build It runs the build and fails with the following error: *ERROR in members.hasOwnProperty is not a function* ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I don't know how to reproduce it. It has occurred during development and without any upgrade to any packages. ## üî• Exception or Error ### Exception on SERVE: No exception can be found except for the above error as told in the description. ### Exception on BUILD: No exception could be found except for the above error.       { path: 'error/:type', component: ErrorPageComponent },
      { path: '', redirectTo: 'dashboard', pathMatch: 'full' },
      { path: '**', redirectTo: 'dashboard', pathMatch: 'full' }
    ]
  },

  { path: '**', redirectTo: 'error/403', pathMatch: 'full' }
];

@NgModule({
  imports: [RouterModule.forRoot(routes)],
  exports: [RouterModule]
})
export class AppRoutingModule {}
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ERROR in No NgModule metadata found for 'AppModule'" (#16706)

Issues.Title: Add dynamic list as additional input type for x-promt (schematic)
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [x] generate

This feature request is actually about extending the functionality of schematics themselves. `ng generate` is just involved as the requested feature would be accessed through the command.

### Description
Today schematic promts are limited to a fixed set of compile time response values. To allow more advanced scaffolding use cases we also need the ability to dynamically (runtime) generated valid response values.

### Describe the solution you'd like
- Add new promt input type `dynamic-list` or similar
- Provide standardized way of filling the dynamic lists from within schematic code

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Open to any suggestions.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add dynamic list as additional input type for x-promt (schematic)" (#16705)

Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [sass](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass) | dependencies | minor | [`1.24.5` -> `1.25.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/sass/1.24.5/1.25.0) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>sass/dart-sass</summary>

### [`v1.25.0`](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​1250)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/sass/dart-sass/compare/1.24.5...1.25.0)

-   Add functions to the built-in "sass:math" module.

    -   `clamp($min, $number, $max)`. Clamps `$number` in between `$min` and `$max`.

    -   `hypot($numbers...)`. Given _n_ numbers, outputs the length of the
        _n_-dimensional vector that has components equal to each of the inputs.

    -   Exponential. All inputs must be unitless.

        -   `log($number)` or `log($number, $base)`. If no base is provided, performs
             a natural log.
        -   `pow($base, $exponent)`
        -   `sqrt($number)`

    -   Trigonometric. The input must be an angle. If no unit is given, the input is
        assumed to be in `rad`.

        -   `cos($number)`
        -   `sin($number)`
        -   `tan($number)`

    -   Inverse trigonometric. The output is in `deg`.
        -   `acos($number)`. Input must be unitless.
        -   `asin($number)`. Input must be unitless.
        -   `atan($number)`. Input must be unitless.
        -   `atan2($y, $x)`. `$y` and `$x` must have compatible units or be unitless.

-   Add the variables `$pi` and `$e` to the built-in "sass:math" module.

##### JavaScript API

-   `constructor.value` fields on value objects now match their Node Sass
    equivalents.

</details>

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/cli): remove use of process.exit
Issues.Body:
process.exit() can cause the loss of asynchronous I/O.  This can include console output which may internally be asynchronous.
Reference: https://nodejs.org/api/process.html#process_process_exit_code


Closing for now pending additional investigation.  It appears that there are pending async tasks that are preventing the natural exit of the application.

Issues.Title: Don't enable `skipLibCheck` in `--strict` mode
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [x] config

### Description
I'm quite surprised by this move: #16682, which enables TypeScript `skipLibCheck` by default. From what I know, it's usually considered as a *temporary* workaround for issues that should be correctly resolved. While it may have performances and compatibility advantages, it degrades types strictness (ie. some real errors may not be reported anymore).

It goes in an opposite way than the new `--strict` option in v9 that finally enables strict mode.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I won't argue on your choice to make `skipLibCheck` the default (I suppose it comes from some issues I'm not aware of), but is it possible to *not* enable it when the `--strict` option has been provided, for people who wants to work with strict types?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Don't enable `skipLibCheck` in `--strict` mode" (#16696)

Issues.Title: Control emitting Ivy class metadata and Angular module scope information
Issues.Body:
This change allows the import eliding capabilities of the plugin to more completely remove the effects of the `setClassMetadata` and `setNgModuleScope` functions.  This provides equivalent behavior to the Decorator removal functionality for View Engine.  As a result, Angular components are no longer retained in chunks that do not use the component.

This corrects the factory code location problem discussed in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16146#issuecomment-557559287.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Control emitting Ivy class metadata and Angular module scope information" (#16694)

Issues.Title: ci: use branch filtering to run `e2e-cli-ng-snapshots` and `e2e-cli-ng-ve-snapshots
Issues.Body:
ci: use branch filtering to run `e2e-cli-ng-snapshots` and `e2e-cli-ng-ve-snapshots`

Unlike PRs from users, when renovate opens a PR, the branch name will be in the following format `renovate/typescript-3.7.x` with `CIRCLE_BRANCH` being set to the same value. Also, `CIRCLE_PR_USERNAME` will not be defined in this case. Thus currently these 2 tasks are not being run for PRs which are being open by renovate.

Example of such build: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular-cli/129384

Issues.Title: File replacements for multiple configs are not getting merged
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? no ### Description With https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/15819# the CLI allows to define multiple configurations that get overlayed. However the merge process of the configs only does a shallow merge, which e.g. for `fileReplacements` means that all replacements in a previous config get overriden. I suggest to do a deep merge on the configurations, not a shallow merge. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Example: with this `angular.json`: ```json { "$schema": "./node_modules/@angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json", "version": 1, "newProjectRoot": "projects", "projects": { "proto-sites-next-app": { "projectType": "application", "schematics": { "@schematics/angular:component": { "style": "scss" } }, "root": "", "sourceRoot": "src", "prefix": "app", "architect": { "build": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser", "options": { "outputPath": "dist/proto-sites-next-app", "index": "src/index.html", "polyfills": "src/polyfills.ts", "tsConfig": "tsconfig.app.json", "main": "src/main.ts", "aot": true, "assets": [ "src/favicon.ico", "src/assets" ], "styles": [ "./node_modules/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css", "./node_modules/sample-sites-next/data/assets/lightTheme/main.css", "src/styles.scss" ], "scripts": [] }, "configurations": { "production": { "fileReplacements": [ { "replace": "src/environments/environment.ts", "with": "src/environments/environment.prod.ts" } ], "optimization": true, "outputHashing": "all", "sourceMap": false, "extractCss": true, "namedChunks": false, "extractLicenses": true, "vendorChunk": false, "buildOptimizer": true, "budgets": [ { "type": "initial", "maximumWarning": "2mb", "maximumError": "5mb" }, { "type": "anyComponentStyle", "maximumWarning": "6kb", "maximumError": "10kb" } ] }, "edit": { "outputPath": "dist/proto-sites-next-app-edit", "fileReplacements": [ { "replace": "src/app/app.bootstrap.module.ts", "with": "src/app/app.bootstrap.edit.module.ts" } ] }, "view": { "outputPath": "dist/proto-sites-next-app-view", "fileReplacements": [ { "replace": "src/app/app.bootstrap.module.ts", "with": "src/app/app.bootstrap.view.module.ts" } ] } } }, "serve": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server", "options": { "browserTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:build" }, "configurations": { "production": { "browserTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:build:production" }, "edit": { "browserTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:build:edit-mode" }, "view": { "browserTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:build:view-mode" } } }, "extract-i18n": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:extract-i18n", "options": { "browserTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:build" } }, "test": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:karma", "options": { "main": "src/test.ts", "polyfills": "src/polyfills.ts", "tsConfig": "tsconfig.spec.json", "karmaConfig": "karma.conf.js", "assets": [ "src/favicon.ico", "src/assets" ], "styles": [ "src/styles.scss" ], "scripts": [] } }, "lint": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:tslint", "options": { "tsConfig": [ "tsconfig.app.json", "tsconfig.spec.json", "e2e/tsconfig.json" ], "exclude": [ "**/node_modules/**" ] } }, "e2e": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:protractor", "options": { "protractorConfig": "e2e/protractor.conf.js", "devServerTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:serve" }, "configurations": { "production": { "devServerTarget": "proto-sites-next-app:serve:production" } } } } }}, "defaultProject": "proto-sites-next-app" } ``` I specify two new configs `edit` and `view`. These configs are logically orthogonal to production vs normal mode, so I would like to be able to build the application e.g. like this: `ng build --configuration=edit` and `ng build --configuration=production,edit` However the later does not work as expected because the file replacements for the environment as defined in the `production` config are overridden. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: `ng e2e --debug`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [X] e2e

### Description
I've been looking for means to debug faulty e2e Protractor tests, however I don't see a means of accomplishing this in the Angular CLI, or a documented solution.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Ideally, I'd like to see some kind of `ng e2e --debug` or `ng e2e --inspect` which builds/runs the application, starts Protractor, and opens up a debugging port. If there is a way to break after test files are loaded, so I can set breakpoints without manually adding a `debugger;` statement, that would be great too.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Most of the material I've found online tells me to call Protractor directly, via something like `node --inspect node_modules/.bin/protractor e2e/protractor.conf.js`. This has a couple problems to me:

1. This is a leaky abstraction.
    * We can do every other execution necessary via the CLI, but not debug e2e tests. As a tangential example, take a look at this [`package.json` scripts configuration](https://github.com/dgp1130/chatter/blob/ng/services/ng-frontend/package.json#L4) I have, all of which just uses `ng` directly, **except** for debugging e2e tests.
    * We do seem to leak Protractor in a few other places (such as the configuration file).
    * Subtle implementation changes in `ng e2e` could cause the debug command to need to be changed. For instance, should I update `webdriver-manager` before running?
1. I don't see any official documentation or stance on how to debug e2e tests; everything I've found is community built.
1. Running Protractor directly also does not boot up the actual application, so a separate `ng serve` command is necessary.
    * I didn't realize this and lost a lot of time debugging, confused why it worked previously and suddenly stopped today. Turns out I had the server running the background last time and didn't realize that was a dependency!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`ng e2e --debug`" (#16683)

Issues.Title: [RFC][PostCSS] Ability to configure PostCSS using config
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request - Ability to configure PostCSS using config


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [x] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [x] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [x] doc

### Description
There a bunch of requests regarding ability to configure PostCSS plugins:
#15766
#8427 
#10076

My proposal more practical and I could prepare PRs for it.

CLI uses PostCSS via `postcss-loader` it has a configuration [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/styles.ts), however plugins list is encapsulated in a function and then applied to multiple loaders (global styles, component styles with/without preprocessors). [`postcss-loader`](https://github.com/postcss/postcss-loader) has a `config` parameter that allows to specify the path to look for PostCSS configuration files (internally it uses [`postcss-load-config`](https://github.com/michael-ciniawsky/postcss-load-config)) and optional context objects to pass to js config files. If CLI will use config configuration for `postcss-loader` it will give the ability to extend/replace plugins, parser, etc. even more it will allow overriding config for specific project/ library/ any folder.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
File: `packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/styles.ts`

PostCSS loader could look like this

```ts
{
  loader: require.resolve('postcss-loader'),
  options: {
      ident: buildOptions.extractCss ? 'extracted' : 'embedded',
      // Config that replaces plugins param
     config: {
         path: root, // root folder path provided by BuilderContext
         ctx: {
           angularCliPlugins: // Here we could pass CLI specific plugins condigs or plugins itself
         }
     },
      sourceMap:
          cssSourceMap && !buildOptions.extractCss && !buildOptions.sourceMap.hidden
              ? 'inline'
               : cssSourceMap,
    },
 },
```

In the root we will have a `postcss.config,js` (it couls be `.postcssrc.js` as well) file:

```js
module.exports = (ctx) => ({
  parser: ctx.parser ? 'sugarss' : false,
  plugins: {
    'postcss-import': ctx.angularCliPlugins.postcssImportOptions,
    'custom-angular-cli-plugin': ctx.angularCliPlugins.otherOptions,
    'autoprefixer': true, // users could opt-out, ex. if postcss-preset-env used
    'postcss-plugin': ctx.options.plugin
  }
})
```

Users will get full control of PostCSS with that configuration, could make it dynamic with `ctx`, etc.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?


Another option is to pass configuration from `angular.json`, but IMO not the best idea as it will make it more complex + CLI exposes configs for `browserslist`, `tslint`, etc. with defaults but users can customize them.

[`ngx-build-plus`](https://github.com/manfredsteyer/ngx-build-plus) could replace part of webpack config, but you might need to hook up into few places (global styles, preprocessor styles loaders and rely on that exact structure of `webpack` config) and you have no control over plugins provided by CLI since they are created with a function call.

[`angular-builders/custom-webpack`](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/tree/master/packages/custom-webpack) has pretty same limitations and open issues related to PostCSS, [see](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/issues/634)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[RFC][PostCSS] Ability to configure PostCSS using config" (#16681)

Issues.Title: fix(youtube-player): not picking up static startSeconds and endSeconds
Issues.Body:
The way the `youtube-player` is set up is that the start and end seconds are observables which means that the consumer will miss out on any values that were emitted before they subscribed. These changes switch them to a `BehaviorSubject` which emits its last value upon subscription.

Also does some internal cleanup in the component.

Fixes #18212.

Issues.Title: youtube-player startSeconds and endSeconds not working
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a wrapper component that uses <youtube-player>, just like the example in the docs except with `startSeconds` and `endSeconds`
```
<youtube-player width="100%" height="100%" 
    videoId="PRQCAL_RMVo" 
    [startSeconds]="40" 
    [endSeconds]="60"
</youtube-player>
```
2. Observe that the startSeconds and endSeconds parameters were not respected. Clicking the play button shows video starting at 0 second.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
I expected to see the video start playing at the 40 second mark.


#### Actual Behavior
This method
```
set startSeconds(startSeconds) {
      this._startSeconds.emit(startSeconds);
}
```
fired before this line in YouTubePlayer.ngOnInit
```
const startSecondsObs = this._startSeconds.pipe(startWith(undefined));
```
The same is true for `endSeconds` and `suggestedQuality`.

The effect is that the initial `startSeconds` and `endSeconds` value specified by the wrapper component is reset to `undefined`

For example: if the template was
```
<youtube-player width="100%" height="100%" 
    videoId="PRQCAL_RMVo" 
    [startSeconds]="40" 
    [endSeconds]="60"
</youtube-player>
```
The property `startSeconds` will trigger `this._startSeconds.emit(40);`, then `startSecondObs` will be set to `startWith(undefined)`, and from there on, the initial values `40` and `60` no longer honored.

Work around: in the component that uses <youtube-player>, use template variables to keep track of startSeconds, endSeconds, and suggestedQuality, and leverage setTimeout or lodash.defer to set those values a 2nd time.

------
Glancing at the code, I believe the correct approach has been handled for videoId, width, and height. It just has not been propagated to startSeconds, endSeconds, and suggestedQuality.

#### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "youtube-player startSeconds and endSeconds not working" (#18212)

Issues.Title: CDK Drag and Drop: Unhandled Promise rejection in _cleanupDragArtifacts when ngbTooltip is used on cdkDrag element.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-wkr9so

Steps to reproduce:
1. Drag element from 'To do' to 'Done'
 
#### Expected Behavior

No exception and it gets inserted normally into the 'Done' list. It works when there is no ngbTooltip used.

Issues.Title: Create a Date Range Picker starting from MatCalendar w 1/2 input/s for selection mechanism
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Create a Date Range Picker component starting from using 2 MatCalendar components (fromCalendar and toCalendar) and 1/2 <mat-form-field> with inputs of type text to see the selection. MatCalendar is also used in MatDatepicker.
The Component should add the possibility to add a range selection from the 2 MatCalendar components. The range can be shown by changing the [dateClass] property of the 2 MatCalendar components with a computation describing each element from the range in css classes (first, first-only, last, last-only, in-between).
The component would keep a fromSelectedDate and a toSelectedDate, which will be updated both by selecting dates from the MatCalendar by click and from manual input in the two form fields.
Either mat-hint or mat-error should be present to validate range from manual input selection.
The mat-error should be shown via a ErrorStateMatcher for the formGroup and 2 custom validators, one for each formControl (validating the date formats), and one for the formGroup (validating the range).
minDate should be updated for the toCalendar, in order to validate the range visually. (fromDate should always be lesser or equal to toDate)
activeDate should be updated for both fromCalendar and toCalendar to update the current views.
If minDate is set to the toCalendar, minDate needs to be updated as well before activeDate in order to properly select current views, when going in the past in the fromCalendar.
When updating fromSelectedDate, toSelectedDate should be updated as well with the fromSelectedDate value. 
Everytime a date changes from fromCalendar, or toCalendar components, updateTodaysDate() should be called in order to update the state of the calendars.

#### Use Case
Would enable DateRange filtering options on lists in software that is using @angular/material, without creating such components from scratch. Node modules are not desirable in this case, since they tend to update late after the @angular upgrades and they tend to reimplement the calendars from scratch. This component would be done on top of existing MatCalendar, so no compatibility issues would stand for it.

I would like to contribute to this component (create it) since I have implemented this on the CRM software that I am currently working on in my day to day life. It would be a nice feature to have in the community, since lots of people have tried to implement this feature in their own software.
I would also like to contribute to the MatCalendar documentation that is currently under @angular/material website, since it doesn't describe how to use [dateClass] with MatCalendarCellCssClasses, activeDate and how to implement on top of MatCalendar, and not reimplement MatCalendar from scratch as several people tried.

Thanks,

Liviu Alexandru Bobocu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Create a Date Range Picker starting from MatCalendar w 1/2 input/s for selection mechanism" (#18203)

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): error in IE/Edge for static disabled binding
Issues.Body:
IE/Edge can throw an error for a datepicker input which has a static `disabled` binding. The error is thrown, because static bindings in Ivy are invoked before the element is in the DOM which browsers seem to have an assertion against.

**Note:** I wasn't able to write a unit test for this, because we need to get a hold of the input during creation mode, before directives are matched, which seems to not be possible with `TestBed`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(datepicker): error in IE/Edge for static disabled binding" (#18202)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap classes
Issues.Body:
ConfigurableFocusTrap is part of a new FocusTrap design that will trap more
than just tab focus.

This commit sets up the classes for the new design, and implements the primary
strategy for preventing focus outside the trap (an event listener that
refocuses the trap). Logic to trap screen reader focus and wrap tab
without the hidden tab stops will be in future commits. Migration of
cdkTrapFocus, MatDialog, etc. will also be in future commits.

This commit does not enable ConfigurableFocusTrap anywhere.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap classes" (#18201)

Issues.Title: MatMenu positioned incorrectly (Chrome on Google Pixel)
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://angular-8-material-menu-size-bug.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open StackBlitz example in Chrome on Google Pixel device
2. Tap the second "Trigger Menu" button
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The rendered menu instance to be positioned at (or near) the top of the viewport so that you are able to scroll and view all 99 items in the list.

I expect this because it seems that when the content of the `MatMenu` instance exceeds the height of the viewport, the menu is sized to roughly the height of the viewport (less a gap of `48px`).


#### Actual Behavior

The menu opens below the button, but is still sized to roughly the height of the viewport. This causes a part of the menu to overflow the bottom of the screen, and you are unable to scroll to see all items within the menu.

It seems to present whenever the trigger is within the top half of the screen (but low down enough to cause the menu to overflow the bottom). Tap the third trigger to see it working correctly.


#### Environment

- Angular: ^8.0.0
- CDK/Material: ^8.2.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 78
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Android 10, Pixel 4

#### Other notes

This works as expected (is positioned near the top of the viewport) on everything other than Chrome on Pixel devices. I've tested across various Pixel models and Android versions - it always shows up in this combo.

It does not present on Google Nexus devices (tested 6P).

Unfortunately I am only able to test one Chrome version (78) so I am unable to rule out that this is a Chrome bug.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu positioned incorrectly (Chrome on Google Pixel)" (#18192)

Issues.Title: Consider switching from SystemJS to RequireJS
Issues.Body:
We should consider switching to RequireJS for consistency in the future. The Bazel karma rules already use it, and the `ts_devserver` does too.

It's unclear what limitations RequireJS brings, and what benefits it has. At first glance, I'm unsure if RequireJS provides a good way to lazily load modules (this worked good in SystemJS).

Also it's unclear how flexible the configuration file is. We should compare the pros/cons and decide based on that, if it makes sense to use RequireJS. It might be also worth exploring other tools/loaders. e.g. there is a webpack rule for Bazel.. but I don't think it's applicable.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider switching from SystemJS to RequireJS" (#18189)
